eta_utility.simulators.fmu moduleÔÉÅ

The FMUSimulator class enables easy simulation of FMU files.

class eta_utility.simulators.fmu.FMUSimulator(_id: int, fmu_path: Path, start_time: TimeStep = 0, stop_time: TimeStep = 1, step_size: TimeStep = 1, names_inputs: Sequence[str] | None = None, names_outputs: Sequence[str] | None = None, init_values: Mapping[str, float] | None = None, *, return_type: str | None = None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: object

FMU simulator object.

Parameters:

  • _id ‚Äì FMU instance ID.

  • fmu_path ‚Äì Path to the FMU file.

  • start_time ‚Äì Simulation start time in seconds.

  • stop_time (float) ‚Äì Simulation stop time in seconds.

  • step_size ‚Äì Simulation step size in seconds.

  • names_inputs ‚Äì List of input names that correspond to names used in the FMU file (e.g. [‚Äòu‚Äô, ‚Äòp‚Äô]). If the step function is going to be used with lists as input values, this list will be used to translate between the list position and the variable name in the FMU.

  • names_outputs ‚Äì List of output names that correspond to names used in the FMU file (e.g. [‚Äòy‚Äô, ‚Äòth‚Äô, ‚Äòthdot‚Äô]). If the step function should return only specific values instead of all results as a dictionary, this parameter can be specified to determine, which parameters should be returned.

  • init_values ‚Äì Starting values for parameters that should be pushed to the FMU with names corresponding to variables in the FMU.

  • return_type (str) ‚Äì ‚Äúdict‚Äù or ‚Äúlist‚Äù. Alter the standard behavior, which is to return lists from the step and get_values functions only if both, ‚Äúnames_inputs‚Äù and ‚Äúnames_outputs‚Äù are specified. This parameter will force the step and get_values functions to always return either dictionaries or lists.

fmu_pathÔÉÅ

Path to the FMU model.

start_timeÔÉÅ

Start time for the simulation in time increments.

stop_timeÔÉÅ

Stopping time for the simulation in time increments (only relevant if run in simulation loop).

step_sizeÔÉÅ

Step size (time) for the simulation in time increments.

model_description: ModelDescriptionÔÉÅ

Model description from the FMU (contains variable names, types, references and more).

fmu: FMU2SlaveÔÉÅ

Instance of the FMU Slave object.

timeÔÉÅ

Current simulation time.

property input_vars: list[str]ÔÉÅ

Ordered list of all available input variable names in the FMU.

property output_vars: list[str]ÔÉÅ

Ordered list of all available output variable names in the FMU.

read_values(names: Sequence[str] | None = None) → dict[str | int, Any] | list[source]ÔÉÅ

Return current values of the simulation without advancing a simulation step or the simulation time.

Parameters:

names ‚Äì Sequence of values to read from the FMU. If this is None (default), all available values will be read.

set_values(values: Sequence[Number | bool] | Mapping[str, Number | bool]) → None[source]ÔÉÅ

Set values of simulation variables without advancing a simulation step or the simulation time.

Parameters:

values ‚Äì Values that should be pushed to the FMU. Names of the input_values must correspond to variables in the FMU. If passing as a Sequence, make sure the order corresponds to the order of the input_vars property.

step(input_values: Sequence[Number | bool] | Mapping[str, Number | bool] | None = None, output_names: Sequence[str] | None = None, advance_time: bool = True, nr_substeps: int | None = None) → dict[str | int, Any] | list[Any][source]ÔÉÅ

Simulate next time step in the FMU with defined input values and output values.

Parameters:

  • input_values ‚Äì Current values that should be pushed to the FMU. Names of the input_values must correspond to variables in the FMU. If passing as a Sequence, make sure the order corresponds to the order of the input_vars property.

  • advance_time ‚Äì Decide if the FMUsimulator should add one timestep to the simulation time or not. This can be deactivated, if you just want to look at the result of a simulation step beforehand, without actually advancing simulation time.

  • nr_substeps ‚Äì if simulation steps are divided into substeps, this value will let the simulator know that no time violation warning is necessary.

Returns:

Resulting input and output values from the FMU with the keys named corresponding to the variables in the FMU.

classmethod simulate(fmu_path: Path, start_time: TimeStep = 0, stop_time: TimeStep = 1, step_size: TimeStep = 1, init_values: Mapping[str, float] | None = None) → np.ndarray[source]ÔÉÅ

Instantiate a simulator with the specified FMU, perform simulation and return results.

Parameters:

  • fmu_path ‚Äì Path to the FMU file.

  • start_time ‚Äì Simulation start time in seconds.

  • stop_time (float) ‚Äì Simulation stop time in seconds.

  • step_size ‚Äì simulation step size in seconds.

  • init_values ‚Äì Starting values for parameters that should be pushed to the FMU with names corresponding to variables in the FMU.

reset(init_values: Mapping[str, float] | None = None) → None[source]ÔÉÅ

Reset FMU to specified initial condition.

Parameters:

init_values ‚Äì Values for initialization.

close() → None[source]ÔÉÅ

Close the FMU and tidy up the unzipped files.

class eta_utility.simulators.fmu.FMU2MESlave(**kwargs: Any)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: FMU2Model

Helper class for simulation of FMU2 FMUs. This is as wrapper for FMU2Model. It can be used to wrap model exchange FMUs such that they can be simulated similar to a co-simulation FMU. This is especially helpful for testing model exchange FMUs.

It exposes an interface that emulates part of the original FMU2Slave class from fmpy.

fmi2True: int = 1ÔÉÅ
fmi2False: int = 0ÔÉÅ
fmi2OK: int = 0ÔÉÅ
fmi2Warning: int = 1ÔÉÅ
fmi2Discard: int = 2ÔÉÅ
fmi2Error: int = 3ÔÉÅ
fmi2Fatal: int = 4ÔÉÅ
fmi2Pending: int = 5ÔÉÅ
setupExperiment(tolerance: float | None = None, startTime: float = 0.0, stopTime: float | None = None, **kwargs: Any) → int[source]ÔÉÅ

Experiment setup and storage of required values.

Parameters:

  • tolerance ‚Äì Solver tolerance, default value is 1e-5.

  • startTime ‚Äì Starting time for the experiment.

  • stopTime ‚Äì Ending time for the experiment.

  • kwargs ‚Äì Other keyword arguments that might be required for FMU2Model.setupExperiment in the future.

Returns:

FMI2 return value.

exitInitializationMode(**kwargs: Any) → int[source]ÔÉÅ

Exit the initialization mode and set up the cvode solver.

See also: fmpy.fmi2.FMU2Model.exitInitializationMode

Parameters:

kwargs ‚Äì Keyword arguments accepted by FMU2Model.exitInitializationMode.

Returns:

FMI2 return value.

doStep(currentCommunicationPoint: float, communicationStepSize: float, noSetFMUStatePriorToCurrentPoint: int | None = None) → int[source]ÔÉÅ

Perform a simulation step. Advance simulation from currentCommunicationPoint by communicationStepSize.

Also refer to the FMI2 Standard documentation.

Parameters:

  • currentCommunicationPoint ‚Äì Current time stamp (starting point for simulation step).

  • communicationStepSize ‚Äì Time step size.

  • noSetFMUStatePriorToCurrentPoint ‚Äì Determine whether a reset before currentCommunicationPoint is possible. Must be either fmi2True or fmi2False.

Returns:

FMU2 return value.
